Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Single-Molecule DNA Sequencing of Antarctic Paleolakes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Despite recent advances, we still know little about how life and its traces persist in extremely harsh conditions. What survival strategies do cells employ when pushed to their limit? Using a new technique, this project will investigate whether Antarctic paleolakes harbor "microbial seed banks," or caches of viable microbes adapted to past paleoenvironments that could help transform our understanding of how cells survive over ancient timescales. Findings from this investigation could also illuminate novel DNA repair pathways with possible biomedical and biotechnology applications and help to refine life detection strategies for Mars. The project will bring Antarctic research to Georgetown University's campus for the first time, providing training opportunities in cutting edge analytical techniques for multiple students and a postdoctoral fellow.

The field site will be the McMurdo Dry Valleys, which provide an unrivaled opportunity to investigate fundamental questions about the persistence of microbial life. Multiple lines of evidence, from interbedded and overlying ashfall deposits to parameterized models, suggest that the large-scale landforms there have remained essentially fixed as far back as the middle of the Miocene Epoch (i.e., ~8 million years ago). This geologic stability, coupled with geographic isolation and a steady polar climate, mean that biological activity has probably undergone few qualitative changes over the last one to two million years. The team will sample paleolake facies using sterile techniques from multiple Dry Valleys sites and extract DNA from entombed organic material. Genetic material will then be sequenced using Pacific Biosciences' Single Molecule, Real-Time DNA sequencing technology, which sequences native DNA as opposed to amplified DNA, thereby eliminating PCR primer bias, and enables read lengths that have never before been possible. The data will be analyzed with a range of bioinformatic techniques, with results that stand to impact our understanding of cell biology, Antarctic paleobiology, microbiology and biogeography, biotechnology, and planetary science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated life in one of the harshest environments on Earth. The McMurdo Dry Valleys are the largest continuous ice-free area of Antarctica. Less than 10cm of precipitation falls annually and most snow is quickly sublimated into a gas. In this hyperarid polar desert, glacial lakes have receded and exposed microbial mats, the desiccated and preserved remains of the paleolake communities. We investigated these deposits, exploring both the community composition and its functional activity in order to understand how cells can survive desiccation and persist over long time scales in such extreme conditions. 

In order to assess these communities, we utilized cutting-edge single-molecule DNA sequencing methods. These new forms of sequencing read native DNA instead of amplification products and do not need to cleave DNA into short fragments for sequencing, allowing for reads that are tens or hundreds of kilobases long. We focused on one form of this sequencing technology, Pacific Bioscience’s Single-Molecule Real-Time sequencing, pairing it with Illumina’s sequencing by synthesis technology to assess the community composition of paleolake deposits in the vicinity of Lake Vanda.  We then coupled this work with RNA sequencing to explore the metabolic activity of the paleomat deposits. We found that the communities showed few signs of dormancy, with high levels of transcription for DNA repair and stress response pathways, giving rise to new insights about the metabolic mechanisms that allow the microbes to survive in the extremely cold and arid environment. 

We also utilized another form of single-molecule sequencing technology, Oxford Nanopore Technology’s highly portable MinION sequencer, to conduct a proof-of-concept experiment sequencing DNA in the field, with battery power and no internet connection, paving the way for the technology to be adopted in other remote field environments. 

In addition, we studied the microbial diversity of the paleomat samples using scanning electron microscopy to visualize the microbial life in the mats. A student project observed various bacterial morphologies, diatoms, and several structures generated by the microbial communities, like biofilms and microbially-deposited minerals. These visualizations give us additional information about the kinds of life persisting in the desiccated mats and some of their activity. 

We are also nearing completion of a second student project, a survey of the microbial ecology of soil samples from several of the valleys. This bioinformatic analysis explores community structure and composition and draws on publicly available genomic datasets to better understand the Antarctic soil communities and their relationship to soils from other environments, to place Antarctic soils in a global context. 

Ultimately, through the support of this project, we have been able to characterize the microbial life surviving in the incredibly dry, dark, and cold conditions of the McMurdo Dry Valleys, expanding our understanding of how life can survive when pushed to its limits.

This work also has implications for astrobiology. The insights into the survival strategies utilized by microbes as well as the utilization of new tools and techniques to characterize them moves us one step closer to integrating similar strategies for life detection in other remote environments, including Mars and other worlds.
